stories.headline: Meyerland bucks citywide crime dip
stories.summary: Despite a citywide increase in crime in Houston since 2019, Meyerland has seen a growth in crime since 1966, according to resident Alan Lipman. He moved back to the neighborhood and noticed changes including increased crime impacting his local area. The article speaks to wider crime trends in Houston and the local impact on residential neighborhoods like Meyerland.

stories.headline: Legislator takes stand against redistricting
stories.summary: State Representative Nicole Collier of Fort Worth is the only Democrat who refused Republican leaders' order to accept a police escort to leave the Texas House chamber during a session protest. Collier expressed frustration with the GOP and spoke against redistricting plans. She faced chants and support outside the chamber while taking reporters' interviews following her refusal. The incident highlights tensions in the Texas House over police orders and legislative processes.

stories.headline: Trump rules out troops in Ukraine
stories.summary: President Donald Trump announced that he will not send U.S. troops to defend Ukraine against Russia, calling hopes for Ukraine's NATO membership 'impossible.' Trump indicated Ukraine's hopes of joining NATO and regaining Crimea are unrealistic. He stated he would have no U.S. military control over Ukraine after his term ends in January 2029. The White House press secretary emphasized that U.S. boots will not be on the ground as part of any peacekeeping mission.

stories.headline: Mold outbreak at courts spurs bathroom closures
stories.summary: Harris County's downtown courthouse complex experienced a mold outbreak that led officials to close dozens of public bathrooms and conduct lab testing. Mold was found on bathrooms used by judges, courthouse workers, and public members on the 14th, 16th, and 17th floors. Judge Brian Warren and his employees belong to the impacted bathrooms. The judge reported the issue in July and noted concerning mold growth in a chamber bathroom.

stories.headline: Worker benefits spared in county budget
stories.summary: Harris County's plan to pare down a $48 million budget deficit spared employee benefits and pension contributions, but could lead to cuts in major departments like Public Health, Engineering, and Housing. Commissioners Adrian Garcia and Lesley Briones advocated trimming positions and cutting costs for efficiencies, though some accused them of spreading false narratives during a news conference. The budget issues stem from a previously approved $1 billion police contract with a 36.5% pay raise.

stories.headline: Immigrant trust in police erodes
stories.summary: Immigrant families in Hillsborough County are increasingly fearful of interacting with local law enforcement due to immigration enforcement crackdowns. This fear has led to weakened community ties with police, causing concerns that people may not report crimes or seek help. The erosion of trust is linked to recent changes in federal immigration policies and partnerships between local authorities and immigration agencies, creating a climate of fear even in situations where police intervention could help resolve serious issues.

stories.headline: Hillsborough animal shelter is without AC. Why it is not rare
stories.summary: During a brutal heat wave at the end of July, Hillsborough County Pet Resource Center made a public appeal to help cool about 260 dogs housed at the shelter. The shelter faced extreme heat with four out of seven kennels lacking air conditioning. Despite donations and increased foster support, issues persist due to the shelter's location and aging infrastructure. Staff and volunteers are concerned about the welfare of the animals as temperatures soar, highlighting ongoing challenges for animal shelters in the region.

stories.headline: Tampa Bay is a hot spot for Israeli companies
stories.summary: Tampa Bay has become a growing hub for Israeli tech companies, supported by a local accelerator that has attracted dozens of businesses to Florida. This influx includes firms focused on advanced military and drone technologies. While some local leaders across the political spectrum have welcomed the economic boost, others express concerns about the ethical implications of these technologies. The trend reflects increasing Israeli business expansion in the U.S. with Tampa Bay as a strategic location.

stories.headline: Fedorov honor a sign ice has thawed - Red Wings to finally retire star’s jersey
stories.summary: The Detroit Red Wings announced plans to retire Sergei Fedorov’s No. 91 jersey on January 12, 2026, ending a long wait for this honor. Team owner and CEO Christopher Ilitch revealed the decision, highlighting Fedorov's importance to the team. The article also touches on Mike Ilitch’s influence and legacy in hockey as the father of Christopher.

stories.headline: Hopefuls on how to shield city kids - Sheffield, Kinloch take aim at roots of violence
stories.summary: Detroit mayoral candidates Mary Sheffield and Solomon Kinloch focus on addressing the roots of violence affecting the city’s youth. Despite a decrease in overall crime, juvenile gun violence remains a critical concern, with many youths shot or injured this summer. The candidates emphasize community intervention efforts and protecting children from violence to foster safer neighborhoods.

stories.headline: Hurricane Erin starts trek up East Coast
stories.summary: Hurricane Erin began its journey up the East Coast as a Category 3 storm with 115 mph winds, later downgraded to Category 2. The hurricane caused rip currents and high waves, prompting mandatory evacuations along the North Carolina coast and affecting thousands of beachgoers and residents. Emergency officials rescued at least 60 people caught in rip currents during the storm.

stories.headline: AI, tariff uncertainty leaves new college graduates out in cold job market
stories.summary: Recent college graduates are struggling to find entry-level work due to unclear impacts of artificial intelligence advancements and tariffs on the economy. Companies are cautious in hiring, expecting job growth to slow in 2024. Experts note increased difficulty for new graduates to find jobs in their fields, with many settling for lower wages or underemployment. The Federal Reserve Bank reports a decrease in employment rates for recent graduates, further highlighting challenges in the job market.

stories.headline: Rules block 'anti-American' migrants
stories.summary: The Department of Homeland Security is implementing President Trump's "America First" policy to block immigration benefits for undocumented migrants who exhibit anti-American behavior such as posting or expressing common causes with terrorism or antisemitism. USCIS will consider these actions when reviewing applications for legal status upgrades, aiming to restrict benefits for those who do not support American values and interests. Immigration agencies are also promoting anti-American ideologies as a justification.

stories.headline: Trump rules out U.S. troops in Ukraine
stories.summary: President Trump announced he will not deploy U.S. troops to Ukraine amidst ongoing conflict, instead promoting the use of American airpower to prevent further Russian invasions. He reassured that no American boots would be on the ground at the Ukrainian border and emphasized diplomatic efforts involving European partners. The announcement came after talks with leaders Putin and Zelenskyy and amidst ongoing peace discussions between Russia and Ukraine.

stories.headline: China blasts Golden Dome as space threat
stories.summary: China is opposing President Trump's Golden Dome plan, a national missile defense system, saying it leads to an arms race and escalates tensions with Beijing. Chinese Defense and Foreign Ministry officials criticize the U.S. missile shield, claiming it undermines strategic stability and could provoke countermeasures. The report highlights Beijing's objections to the missile shield and accuses the U.S. of Cold War mentality influencing the program.

stories.headline: Biden team warned on autopenned pardons
stories.summary: A top Justice Department official cautioned the Biden administration that thousands of last-minute pardons signed by autopenners were legally flawed and could result in unintended consequences including commutations for violent offenders. Associate Deputy Attorney General Bradley Weinheimer criticized the use of vague language in these pardons and raised questions about the reviewers' legal expertise. The official review followed scrutiny over the volume and legality of pardons issued at the end of Biden's term.

stories.headline: Hobbs defends mail-in voting after new Trump attacks
stories.summary: Arizona Governor Katie Hobbs filed for re-election and defended mail-in voting as a secure and fair method amid attacks by former President Trump. Hobbs emphasized the importance of protecting voting rights and freedoms in Arizona, opposing Trump's efforts to undermine mail-in ballots. She noted her rise in politics was driven by a commitment to fight for accessible voting rights and vowed to continue to defend these rights.

stories.headline: Trump seeks fast Russia-Ukraine deal
stories.summary: President Donald Trump is determined to make a deal quickly to end the war in Ukraine. European leaders and Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskyy are engaged in efforts to reach a peace agreement. Allies praise Trump's leadership on the need to reach a ceasefire before negotiations, but Russian President Vladimir Putin has ruled out a ceasefire in his meeting with Trump, complicating the prospect for an accord.

stories.headline: Appeals court blocks land swap for Oak Flat
stories.summary: A federal appeals court temporarily halted a land exchange allowing construction of a copper mine on sacred land held by Arizona tribes. The ruling came just before the swap could have been completed, extending a 60-day review period. Environmentalists, tribes, and the San Carlos Apache Tribe had requested the injunction, halting the exchange until the case can be heard further.

stories.headline: Beau Bayh’s return rouses Indiana Dems’ political hopes
stories.summary: Beau Bayh has re-entered the political scene in Indiana, drawing attention given his family's legacy including his late mother, former Indiana first lady Susan Bayh, and father, former governor Evan Bayh. At 29, Beau Bayh is viewed by some Indiana Democrats as a promising candidate to regain political power and restore the party’s relevance, reminiscent of the influence his family held when his father was in office.

stories.headline: Trump eyes swift deal over allies' warnings
stories.summary: President Donald Trump is determined to make a quick deal to end the war in Ukraine, despite NATO partners rejecting land swap proposals. For Ukraine and European leaders, this prospect is concerning. Trump's effort to reach an agreement has gained momentum from his Nobel Peace Prize campaign and support from European leaders, with backing from the White House for a swift resolution to the conflict.

stories.headline: Email: Ex-sheriff knew of sex abuse claims
stories.summary: A newly disclosed email contradicts previous claims by former Henry County Sheriff Ric McCorkle that he was unaware of a 2018 sexual abuse allegation against a community corrections official who was also his deputy. The accuser is among several men now suing Henry County leaders for failing to prevent the abuse. McCorkle admitted he was unaware at the time but an email suggests he had some knowledge. The email is part of recent evidence relating to allegations against deputy Jason Bertram.

stories.headline: Indy Signia hotel reaches key milestone
stories.summary: The construction of the Indy Signia hotel, a sleek 38-story tower by Hilton, has reached a significant milestone with over 50% completion, ahead of schedule. The hotel will dramatically change downtown Indianapolis' skyline and expand the Indiana Convention Center's footprint, boosting the city's tourism economy with more hotel rooms and meeting spaces for conventions. Capital Improvement Board officials gave reporters a tour of the site on August 18 as work continues towards the 2026 opening.

stories.headline: Ocean City closes water due to storm
stories.summary: The Ocean City Beach Patrol and Assateague State Park closed the ocean to swimming, wading, and surfing due to dangerous conditions from a tropical storm. Visitors and residents are advised to stay clear of water activities during the storm for safety reasons.

stories.headline: Sun columnist Jules Witcover dies at 98
stories.summary: Jules Witcover, a veteran Baltimore Sun journalist known for his decades-long career covering political columns, passed away at the age of 98. Witcover was recognized for his insightful and thorough reporting throughout his lengthy career.

stories.headline: Trump: No US troops to Ukraine
stories.summary: President Donald Trump assured that no U.S. troops would be sent to help defend Ukraine against Russia amid ongoing tensions. Trump emphasized that American troops would not be part of defending Ukraine's border and expressed his role as president to manage the involvement. The stance was made a day after not ruling out peacekeeping roles.

stories.headline: Moore’s press secretary leaves for a new role
stories.summary: Maryland Governor Wes Moore’s press secretary has left his state government role to join a senior advisory role for the governor’s reelection campaign. This staff change indicates a shift in the administration's communication team as the political season begins shaping up.

stories.headline: Missouri axed its capital gains tax. Maryland is doing the opposite
stories.summary: Missouri became the first state to eliminate capital gains taxes while Maryland is increasing them with a new budget. Missouri moves in one direction by removing the tax but Maryland’s fiscal 2026 budget introduces a surcharge to tax gains for high earners at a uniform 2%. This politics-driven divergence highlights differing state approaches to taxation of investment income.

stories.headline: Judge’s views could complicate Trump’s suit against courts
stories.summary: A U.S. district court judge overseeing President Trump's administration’s pending lawsuit against 11 Maryland federal judges has emphasized judicial independence. Thomas Cullen, appointed by Trump, expressed the importance of judicial independence while commenting on the court challenges raised by the Trump administration.

stories.headline: Justice Dept. investigates whether DC falsified data
stories.summary: The Justice Department has opened an investigation into whether police officials in Washington, D.C. falsified crime data to make crime rates appear lower. The probe was prompted by reports from people familiar with the matter and growing scrutiny over data accuracy in D.C. following criticism from President Trump and an online post by a national intelligence official.

stories.headline: Explosion halts cargo ship traffic
stories.summary: A coal carrier near the site of the Key Bridge collapse was damaged after an explosion on board the Liberian cargo ship W-Sapphire. The explosion caused a fire, and all 23 crew members were accounted for with no injuries. Officials are investigating the cause as the damaged ship anchors north of the Chesapeake Bay Bridge.

stories.headline: State transportation agency looking ahead to next year
stories.summary: The Alabama Department of Transportation (ALDOT) is nearing completion of its Beltline Road resurfacing project but is already planning roadwork for next year. ALDOT's North Region reconstruction engineer Rod Ellis shared that while some road tie-ins and striping still need to be done, the first two phases of resurfacing from Alabama 24 to Alabama 20 will finish before the fiscal year ends. MPO Director Dewayne Hellums highlighted the collaboration among local officials and ALDOT to fund federal, state, and local transportation projects.

stories.headline: Marquette trial postponed
stories.summary: A Morgan County judge has delayed the murder trial of former Decatur police officer Mac Marquette, while the defense appeals to the Alabama Supreme Court. The postponement follows a judge granting an unopposed defense motion to reset the case for Nov. 17 and 19. The delay prevents prosecutors, defense lawyers, police department employees, and prospective witnesses from commenting, as the immunity fight and other legal maneuvers continue.

stories.headline: Talking students now music to teachers' ears
stories.summary: A new state law known as the FOCUS Act bans the use of cellphones and other smart devices during instructional hours starting this year. While some students, like 16-year-old Jabari Wiggins, felt the ban was unfair due to their reliance on phones for music during breaks, Governor Kay Ivey supports the legislation. The law aims to reduce classroom distractions and promote focused learning by restricting phone use during school hours, although students may still use their phones outside of class time.

stories.headline: Trump says no to US troops going to Ukraine
stories.summary: President Donald Trump affirmed that he would not send U.S. troops to defend Ukraine against Russia despite ongoing war concerns. After recent meetings with Russian President Vladimir Putin, Trump stated American forces will not be involved in Ukraine, asserting no promises to protect Ukrainian interests were made. He emphasized that any deployment of U.S. troops in this conflict would be impossible and highlighted ongoing diplomatic efforts. The President remains hopeful for a deal to end the conflict, underscoring previous administration negotiations and Putin's stance.

stories.headline: Water quality efforts stymied by politics
stories.summary: Hundreds of Iowans recently gathered at Drake University to hear scientists discuss the ongoing threat of agricultural practices to the state's drinking water. A 227-page water quality assessment revealed high nitrate levels, leading to a mandatory lawn-watering ban for 600,000 customers. Despite some improvements, many are concerned the state is not doing enough to solve the problem, with political will seen as lacking for further action.

stories.headline: Council OKs franchise fee hike to fund DART
stories.summary: The Des Moines City Council approved an increase in the fee on gas and electric bills to fund the Des Moines Area Regional Transit Authority. The 4-2 vote included support from Linda Westergaard and Chris Coleman, with opposition from two other council members. The measure is aimed at supporting DART's operations, although no timetable was given for when energy bills will reflect the hike. Mayor approval was noted.

stories.headline: Nuisance nightclub site has been sold
stories.summary: The infamous Zora nightclub site at a prominent intersection in Des Moines has been sold two years after its closure. The property, owned by a credit union after foreclosure, was purchased by Denny Elwell Co. led by CEO Chris Murray. The company plans to retain the custom-built Zora Rooftop & Bar due to its favorable location on the southwest corner of Ingersoll Avenue and Martin Luther King Jr. Parkway.

stories.headline: FCPS board decides to hold occupational license tax hearing
stories.summary: The Fayette County Public Schools board has voted to hold a Sept. 5 public hearing to discuss a potential increase in the occupational license tax. This hearing could lead to a proposal for the tax increase to help support the school district's financial needs. Despite opposition to raising the tax, the board sees it as a necessary step to address budget shortfalls. The district faces a projected $16 million deficit for the upcoming school year.

stories.headline: KY Senate candidate wants to stop all immigration
stories.summary: U.S. Senate candidate Nate Morris proposes halting all legal immigration to the United States until all undocumented immigrants are deported. He argues that current immigration levels are unsustainable and would amount to a national disaster. Morris supports no exceptions for work visas, student visas, or other special immigrant categories and separates himself from other Republicans in the race by maintaining this firm stance on immigration.

stories.headline: Fired juvenile justice officer says she wasn’t trained
stories.summary: A former rookie correctional officer, Nickie Jean Terry, who was fired from the Kentucky Department of Juvenile Justice for threatening to pepper spray a teen boy while locked in his cell, claims she was not properly trained for the job. She stated that she was overworked and lacked necessary training or supervision during her less than two-month tenure at the Adair Regional Juvenile Detention Center. The facility has a history of violence, including a riot and sexual assault in recent years.

stories.headline: Takeaways from Trump's meeting with Zelenskyy
stories.summary: President Donald Trump met with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and European leaders at the White House. The meeting focused on the security guarantees the United States would provide Ukraine if Zelenskyy agreed to a deal to end the fighting. Trump also discussed the possibility of a direct meeting between Zelenskyy and Russian President Vladimir Putin, although the timing and occurrence of such a meeting remain unclear. The leaders presented a relatively united front during the talks.

stories.headline: Lawsuit says Idaho’s latest anti-drag crusade began with lie
stories.summary: North Idaho drag performer Eric Posey sued a local blogger for defamation after facing false allegations of exposing himself to minors at the 2022 Pride festival. A jury later awarded Posey $1.1 million in damages. The lawsuit claims that the Idaho Family Policy Center used the allegation to justify a controversial bill aimed at restricting drag performances in front of minors. The Center denies the claims, but critics say the case exemplifies how misleading accusations were used to fuel anti-drag legislation.

stories.headline: Did Kohberger utter victim’s name during attack?
stories.summary: A newly released Idaho State Police report reveals conflicting details about an attack involving Bryan Kohberger. The report references an initial interview with a surviving roommate who said Kohberger used a victim's name during the attack. However, a follow-up interview with the same roommate days later conflicts with this account. Idaho State Police investigator Darren Gilbertson expressed skepticism about Kohberger mentioning a victim's name. The report also notes that a subpoenaed roommate was unharmed, but quietly left the attack scene, adding complexity to the investigation.

stories.headline: New mining deal gives Shoshone-Paiute a ‘seat at the table’
stories.summary: The Shoshone-Paiute Tribes have signed an agreement with Integra Resources, a Canadian mining company, granting them involvement in managing environmental impacts of a mining site and its reclamation. This agreement comes after long legal challenges and objections regarding environmental and tribal concerns. The deal represents progress for the tribes to prevent water loss and environmental damage while having a voice in the mining operations that affect their ancestral homelands in Central Idaho.

stories.headline: Snake River invertebrates killed in invasive mussel fight
stories.summary: Invasive quagga mussels found in Idaho's Snake River in 2023 are microscopic but pose a significant ecological threat. State officials flooded the Twin Falls area with over 40,000 pounds of copper poison to eradicate these mussels. However, the treatment was unsuccessful and repeated in 2024. Despite the risk to other river species, officials proceeded because the mussels could devastate Idaho's economy and ecosystem. A study found 90% of invertebrates near the area were affected by the copper treatment, potentially risking the river's food resources. The treatments did not eliminate the mussels, and further assessments are ongoing.

stories.headline: Summer camp costly for many parents
stories.summary: As summer ends, many parents face the high financial burden of child care and summer camp costs, which have risen to surpass the average cost of rent in all 50 states. Experts offer tips for managing expenses and highlight concerns about rising debt as parents struggle to cover these child care and summer activity costs.

stories.headline: Economists: Trump policies slow growth
stories.summary: Economic experts warn that President Donald Trump's aggressive economic policies are expected to slow U.S. growth and increase the risk of recession or stagflation. While these policies may prevent short-term inflation, they do not foster sustainable economic growth under Trump's four-year term, according to economist Justin Begley.

stories.headline: Paving way to carbon-neutral cities
stories.summary: Cornell University developed a new energy modeling tool that aids the city of Ithaca in planning a path to carbon neutrality by 2030. The model, created by Associate Professor Timur Dogan and his team, simulates small city energy use and helps forecast outcomes to guide carbon-reduction policies.

stories.headline: $3B health care expense looms
stories.summary: New York must prepare to cover nearly $3 billion for health care coverage for half a million residents losing federally funded care due to federal law changes. The $3 billion expense derives from a tax and spending cuts package enacted by Republicans in Congress and President Donald Trump, causing drastic budget challenges for New York's health programs.

stories.headline: California legislators spar in redistricting hearing
stories.summary: A heated California legislative hearing devolved into a shouting match as a Republican lawmaker clashed with Democrats over partisan map redrawing to favor Democrats in upcoming Congressional races. Assemblymember David Tangipa and committee members debated the proposed redistricting plan, with vocal reactions from supporters and opponents during the session.

stories.headline: No US troops in Ukraine, Trump vows
stories.summary: President Donald Trump assured that U.S. troops would not be sent to help defend Ukraine against Russia, stating that the chances of Ukraine joining NATO and regaining Crimea from Russia are 'impossible.' He emphasized that American troops would not be part of defending Ukraine's border, despite questions from journalists and ongoing conflict concerns.

stories.headline: Mexico’s president denies drug enforcement deal
stories.summary: Mexico’s President Claudia Sheinbaum denied any agreement with the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration related to a new initiative to collaborate in combating drug cartels. This statement came following reports of the U.S. deploying missile destroyers near Venezuela and accusations about a so-called 'flagship operation.' The Mexican government asserts no formal agreement has been reached with the DEA.

stories.headline: Meteor lights up night sky over Eureka Springs
stories.summary: A fireball meteor was seen streaking over Eureka Springs late Tuesday night, producing bright light and fragments possibly falling to the ground. Experts explained the meteor was likely part of the Discovery television show 'Meteorite Men' experience, highlighting the phenomenon and its impact on local observers who witnessed the sky illumination.

stories.headline: LR board approves study of deck park
stories.summary: The Little Rock Board of Directors approved a $2.5 million study for a potential deck park over a key portion of Interstate 30, despite opposition from some board members. This move goes against the advice of the city's master plan but is supported for possible urban revitalization. Funding and future project details remain in discussion with city planners and engineering firms.

stories.headline: 'Psychological warfare.' Internal data shows true nature of Alligator Alcatraz
stories.summary: Daniel Ortiz, a Colombian national detained at Alligator Alcatraz with no criminal record, continues to fight for asylum after extended stays in the Everglades immigration detention camp. Internal documents and his legal team's accounts describe the detention center as a site of psychological warfare, with indefinite detention possibilities creating immense stress. Stories like Ortiz’s highlight the harsh realities for migrants at this controversial site, challenging the more benign public image often presented.

stories.headline: As U.S. warships approach Caribbean waters, Maduro mobilizes 4.5 million militia members
stories.summary: In response to an increased U.S. military presence in the Caribbean, Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro announced a special mobilization of more than 4.5 million militia members to defend national sovereignty. This move coincides with U.S. Navy destroyers nearing the southern Caribbean and Washington's decision to raise the bounty for Maduro's capture to $50 million. Maduro, facing U.S. prosecution and sanctions, declared the militia mobilization during a televised event, emphasizing the need to counter what he described as extravagant and hostile threats from the U.S.

stories.headline: 'SHUT IT DOWN' - Every Sunday, they come to pray outside Alligator Alcatraz
stories.summary: Every Sunday, more than 200 people, including revs, rabbis, pastors, and people of multiple faiths, gather in prayer outside Alligator Alcatraz, an immigration detention center near Ochopee. The group shares personal stories and religious testimonies condemning the inhumane treatment of detainees. This weekly vigil has grown as a protest against Florida's immigration detention policies, drawing attention to what participants see as unjust practices at the site.

stories.headline: Company in fatal Turnpike crash has had unsafe trucks and unlicensed drivers: records
stories.summary: The Florida Turnpike crash that killed three South Floridians involved a company with a history of 25 safety violations in the past two years, including unlicensed drivers. The company, White Hawk Carriers, based in Ceres, California, had an insurance policy canceled and was not authorized to operate as a motor carrier in Florida. Despite ongoing issues, it remains authorized to operate in California. The company recently took down its Facebook page and currently lists itself as permanently closed following public scrutiny of the crash.

stories.headline: Relief in Europe, unease in Russia over talk of Ukraine’s security
stories.summary: European leaders returned from a damage control mission to the White House after President Donald Trump downplayed the United States' role in securing peace with Russia, causing unease amid the ongoing Ukraine conflict. Trump appeared to temper expectations regarding a peace deal and suggested the U.S. might not commit troops to a peacekeeping mission, despite European efforts. Russia's Foreign Ministry rejected restrictions on NATO forces near Ukraine and warned against unauthorized escalation. Discussions continue among global leaders on Ukraine's security and the potential for a future peace arrangement.

stories.headline: Parker says she’s upbeat on funding for SEPTA
stories.summary: Philadelphia Mayor Cherelle L. Parker expressed confidence amid standoff discussions with Republicans and Democrats over SEPTA's funding. With service cuts imminent, Parker maintains 'constant communication' with state leaders and asserts that a deal to provide funding lifeline will be found. Parker emphasized her support for mass transit in Philadelphia and Pennsylvania, highlighting ongoing efforts to secure necessary resources to prevent service disruptions.

stories.headline: Swimming bans, flood advisories at the Shore ahead of Hurricane Erin
stories.summary: Several towns on the Jersey Shore have declared Atlantic off-limits due to rising dangers ahead of Hurricane Erin, with swimming bans and flood advisories issued amid expectations of high tides and hazardous ocean conditions. The National Weather Service warned of minor coastal flooding and strong rip currents, urging residents and visitors to take appropriate precautions. Surf conditions are expected to be severe, affecting multiple shore towns and limiting typical water activities.

stories.headline: TRUMP OFFICIALS CLAIM POWER TO BLOCK BILLIONS IN SPENDING
stories.summary: Budget chief Russell Vought claims authority to freeze billions of dollars in spending approved by Congress, asserting the Trump administration's power to withhold funds from low-income housing, medical research, and other programs. This executive action aims to increase budget leverage and cut spending, with Republican-controlled chambers largely acquiescing. However, various congressional members and watchdog groups have expressed concern over the use of this power and its implications for funding commitments and transparency.

stories.headline: Trump says U.S. troops won't be deployed to defend Ukraine
stories.summary: President Donald Trump confirmed in a Tuesday interview that he has assurances no U.S. troops will be sent to defend Ukraine in its conflict with Russia. He also stated that Ukraine's attempts to join NATO or regain the Crimean Peninsula are "impossible." Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and other European leaders met with Trump and other allied leaders recently.

stories.headline: Roy backs push to ban stock trades in Congress
stories.summary: U.S. Representative Michael McCaul's family stock transactions came under scrutiny after a disclosure that his family sold significant amounts of stock following a chip manufacturer’s downgraded forecast. Roy supports proposals to ban stock trading by members of Congress to prevent perceived conflicts of interest tied to insider knowledge, noting that such trades have become common practice in Washington.

stories.headline: Collier takes stand against redistricting
stories.summary: State Representative Nicole Collier, the only Democrat who refused a police escort to leave the chamber, staged a protest inside the Texas House. She stayed overnight and live-streamed from the chamber to oppose the Republican leaders' redistricting plan and the order to leave by police escort, emphasizing that no one should be in custody unnecessarily.

stories.headline: Zerwas focused on labor of 'love'
stories.summary: John Zerwas, expected to be named the new chancellor for the University of Texas System, has a career dedicated to making a difference in education. Zerwas is seen as an educator motivated by a genuine passion for higher education and aims to lead the UT System towards balancing federal research funds with combating 'woke' education tendencies.

stories.headline: Laughter is dying down in cinemas
stories.summary: Comedy films are seeing declining success at the box office, though there remains some hope for the genre. The state of Hollywood comedies has been struggling, especially with pandemic and post-pandemic effects. Many crowd-pleasing films have not performed well recently, and some recent comedies have tried to recover with releases such as 'The Naked Gun' reboot and sequels to popular series. The genre continues to face challenges but is still evolving with new approaches.

stories.headline: Ancestral land returned to tribe
stories.summary: A church transferred a half-acre plot of land to the San Gabriel Band of Mission Indians, marking a significant land return after centuries. The land was signed over on July 10, marking the first such transfer in generations. This act reconnects the tribe to their ancestral land after a long history of dispossession and removals. Elder representatives from the tribe emphasized the importance of this return for cultural and educational purposes.

stories.headline: The best and worst freeways in Southland
stories.summary: The Los Angeles Times ranks freeways in Southern California from the easy and breezy 261 to the imperfect 10 based on factors such as speed, crashes, and other relevant data points. Although no freeway is perfect, the analysis combines important data to evaluate congestion, delays, and safety. The review uses California's Caltrans Performance Measurement System data from 2022 to rank the area's freeways for commuters and drivers.

stories.headline: Maker of voting machines had ‘slush fund,’ feds allege
stories.summary: An election technology firm allegedly overbilled Los Angeles County for voting machines used in the 2020 election and funneled extra cash into a 'slush fund' to bribe government officials, federal prosecutors say. The case involves prosecutors in a Florida federal corruption case against company co-founder Roger Alejandro Piñate and others. The firm, Smartmatic, is accused of inflating voting machine prices and using surplus money to bribe local officials to secure contracts worth $182 million. Prosecutors did not implicate those who benefited from the slush fund, but allege corruption influenced several elections.

stories.headline: How state plans to boost EVs with no federal help
stories.summary: California officials plan to restore subsidies and implement various strategies to boost electric vehicle adoption despite the absence of federal support. The approach aims to maintain the state's zero-emission mandates and includes reinstating tax credits for electric vehicles. Without federal rebates, California's current efforts may fall short in reducing greenhouse gas emissions and meeting air quality standards. The state government emphasizes the importance of supporting clean vehicles to encourage wider electric vehicle sales amid a nationwide decline in subsidies.

stories.headline: Trump: No U.S. troop role in Ukraine
stories.summary: President Trump stated that U.S. troops would not be sent to help defend Ukraine against Russia. He ruled out sending forces to Ukraine or rejoining NATO, labeling the notion of regaining the Crimean peninsula as impossible. This came after meetings with European leaders and administrators related to Ukraine's ongoing conflict. Trump's remarks effectively close the door on direct U.S. military involvement, despite ongoing tensions in the region.

stories.headline: Statewide alert on Windham shooter was sent late and in error, police say
stories.summary: Nearly every phone in Maine received a notification about a gunman at large due to a geo-fencing mistake, with the alert sent over two hours after the shooting. The suspect shot multiple times and was pursued in a manhunt along Route 302 in Windham. The police department acknowledged an error in sending the alert statewide and the delay in notification.

stories.headline: Maine food businesses, shoppers seeing higher costs as tariffs hit
stories.summary: Since launching Claw Coffee Roasters, owner Troy Cobb has faced business challenges due to a 50% tariff on Brazilian coffee beans. The tariff, imposed by President Donald Trump on Brazilian goods, has driven up coffee prices significantly, affecting specialty coffee roasters and other food businesses in Maine. Many businesses, including wine and specialty foods seller Vessel & Vine, have seen price increases especially in imported items.

stories.headline: Vietnam vet whose injury shined light on poor VA care laid to rest back home
stories.summary: Leroy J. Bailey, a Vietnam War veteran who lost his face to a mortar blast, was laid to rest in Augusta. His story highlighted issues in VA care. Bailey lived for over 30 years after his injury, which left a 3-inch-deep hole in his face. He was honored with military honors three years after his death in Lacrosse, Indiana.

stories.headline: 1 year later, Brunswick residents still fear toxic foam spill’s impacts
stories.summary: One year after Maine's largest recorded spill of firefighting foam contaminated the environment, residents near Brunswick remain worried about the impact on their water and health. The spill involved 1,450 gallons of aqueous film-forming foam mixed with water from an airport site that was redeveloped. Community members expressed ongoing apprehension about water safety and health consequences from the PFAS contamination.

stories.headline: President rejects US troops in Ukraine
stories.summary: President Trump stated that no American ground troops would be sent to Ukraine, despite ongoing conflicts and a potential peace agreement with Russia. Trump emphasized US air support could be provided but ruled out boots on the ground. His comments came ahead of meetings with European leaders and Ukraine President Zelensky aimed at ending the war and came after a recent visit by Russian President Putin to Alaska. The situation remains tense with Russia opposing international force presence on its borders.

stories.headline: Pittsfield school failed to halt abuse of girls, review finds
stories.summary: An investigation has found that the leadership of Miss Hall's School in Pittsfield allowed the sexual abuse of at least five female students over 20 years and failed to respond adequately to reports of abuse. The Aleta Law Firm's independent investigation revealed involvement of multiple staff members in misconduct and grooming. The report criticizes the school's handling of the incidents and emphasizes the need for better policies and oversight to protect students from sexual abuse.

stories.headline: Losing weight and, sometimes, friends
stories.summary: In a commentary, Marcia Berry discusses the emotional and social challenges of losing weight, particularly when using a weight-loss drug that made her feel better but created distance in some friendships. She reflects on how losing weight changes dynamics with others who may not understand the journey and adds that friendship boundaries and honesty are important in these situations. Berry advocates for empathy and support for those undergoing such changes.

stories.headline: US investigates controversial arrest in Lawrence
stories.summary: Federal prosecutors are investigating the arrest of a Black man by a Lawrence police captain during a noise complaint in 2023, amid concerns about excessive use of force. Several officers have testified to a grand jury, and a civil rights lawsuit has been filed against the city. The case is part of a wider probe into police accountability and use of force in the area. The investigation remains ongoing with union representatives declining to comment.

stories.headline: More diverse yet more economically divided
stories.summary: A new report by The Boston Indicators reveals that housing in Greater Boston is becoming increasingly segregated by income, with a growing divide between wealthy and low-income residents. The study shows that 43% of Greater Boston's low- and high-income households lived segregated from each other in 2023, up from 32% in 1980. This economic segregation reflects a broader trend of wealthier people living among themselves and lower-income residents doing the same, resulting in fewer mixed-income neighborhoods.

stories.headline: Peace talks’ outlook fogs up
stories.summary: The White House reported that Russian President Vladimir Putin agreed to meet with Ukrainian President Zelensky, but officials express growing doubts about the success of peace talks amid conflicting Kremlin statements and a challenging negotiation environment.

stories.headline: Donbas hangs on amid uncertain fate
stories.summary: As Russia negotiates over the territorial control of Donbas, residents are experiencing ongoing violence and uncertainty. The conflict continues with heavy fighting in eastern Ukraine, including in cities like Kramatorsk and Bilozerka, as both Ukrainian and Russian forces maneuver amid failed peace talks.

stories.headline: D.C. data on crime faces DOJ inquiry
stories.summary: The Justice Department is investigating allegations that D.C. police manipulated crime data to make crime rates appear lower, escalating tensions between the Trump administration and local officials. The inquiry focuses on accusations of "fake crime numbers" and concerns about a potential federal takeover of law enforcement in D.C.

stories.headline: 7-year-old U.S. citizen is stuck in China as father stands trial for his art
stories.summary: A seven-year-old U.S. citizen, the son of artist Mao Zedong, is trapped in China and unable to leave due to his father's legal battles related to controversial artwork. The situation highlights complexities of international family separations amid legal prosecutions and political sensitivities.

stories.headline: Brazilian judge, facing Trump’s ire, is steadfast
stories.summary: Brazilian judge Alexandre de Moraes remains firm against U.S. President Donald Trump's criticisms after imposing penalties on Trump and his supporters in Brazil. Moraes has faced backlash for his judicial decisions but continues to uphold them amidst political pressure.

stories.headline: Eastern Seaboard braces for Hurricane Erin to pass
stories.summary: The East Coast is preparing for the impact of Hurricane Erin, which is expected to pass over North Carolina and cause heavy flooding, dangerous waves, and rip currents over a large area despite the storm not making direct landfall.

stories.headline: Pirro won’t bring cases on carrying long guns
stories.summary: Jeannie Pirro, D.C.'s newly appointed solicitor general, stated she will not prosecute individuals for carrying rifles or shotguns under the district’s gun laws, which she argues violate Supreme Court rulings, signaling a significant shift in local gun enforcement policies.

stories.headline: Groups say data center posed threat
stories.summary: A proposed data center in St. Charles that would have dumped five million gallons of water into Dardenne Creek is facing opposition from environmental groups and state conservation officials. Concerns include significant irreversible threats to endangered wildlife and plant species, as well as increased flooding risks for nearby rural community residents. After pushback from a conservative nonprofit and public opposition dubbed 'Project Cumulus,' the company decided to withdraw the proposal and reconsider its plans to address environmental and community concerns.

stories.headline: Proud Boys billboard near high school is taken down
stories.summary: A billboard promoting a far-right extremist group, the Proud Boys, was removed near a high school in Clinton County after a backlash. The group is described as a self-declared 'Western chauvinists' organization. The billboard appeared near Central Community High School about 40 miles east of St. Louis, prompting complaints and a board decision to take it down. The chairman acknowledged that the billboard would not be tolerated in the community, highlighting ongoing tensions surrounding extremist group promotions near educational institutions.

stories.headline: Tornado cleanup cost soars to $730M
stories.summary: The cost of cleaning up damage from the May 16 tornado in St. Louis has soared to nearly $730 million, more than double early estimates. The federal government will cover a quarter of the cost, with the state responsible for about $180 million. The revised estimate includes new housing developments, infrastructure, and asbestos removal, complicating recovery plans. Officials emphasize the scale and urgency of the rebuilding efforts, amid concerns about additional local costs if redevelopment slows.

stories.headline: Hanaway headed back to capital
stories.summary: Gov. Mike Kehoe appointed Catherine Hanaway as the next Missouri Attorney General, replacing Andrew Bailey who was chosen by Trump for a job with the FBI. Hanaway, with long experience in the St. Louis legal and political scene, is set to take over the 400-person office on Sept. 8, becoming the first woman attorney general in Missouri history to serve the remaining three years of Bailey's term. The appointment highlights Hanaway's career as a former U.S. attorney and state representative, praised for her prosecutorial passion.

stories.headline: U.S. ground troops won't be going to Ukraine, Trump says
stories.summary: President Donald Trump asserted that American ground troops would not be sent to Ukraine despite ongoing discussions about supporting the country amid its conflict with Russia. Trump emphasized that the U.S. would avoid deploying boots on the ground and underlined Russia's rejection of an international force on its borders.

stories.headline: A tax credit favors private schools, and Washington has a choice
stories.summary: The article discusses a federal program that allows individual Americans to donate to nonprofits and receive tax credits, part of the 'One Big Beautiful Bill' initiative. This program would fund scholarships mostly benefiting private K-12 schools, sparking debate about its impact on public education and the future direction Washington should take.

stories.headline: Everett woman details 'humiliating' ordeal in ICE custody with her son
stories.summary: Sarah Shaw, a Washington state employee, recounts her three-week detention experience in a Texas Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility with her 6-year-old son. She describes the lack of privacy and space, and the emotional toll of incarceration with her youngest child due to a paperwork issue.

stories.headline: Seattle-area real estate agents go where homebuyers scroll
stories.summary: Real estate agents in the Seattle area are shifting their marketing strategies to focus on online platforms like Instagram Reels and TikTok, where potential homebuyers spend a lot of time. Agents are building influencer-like presences to attract clients and show properties virtually, leveraging social media's broad reach despite some polarized opinions about these platforms.

stories.headline: 2 more Fred Meyer stores in Seattle, Redmond to close
stories.summary: Kroger, the parent company of Fred Meyer, announced it will close two more of its Seattle-area stores by mid-October, joining four other recent closures. This decision affects about 700 workers and is attributed to concerns over rising theft and a challenging regulatory environment.

stories.headline: Same-sex couples still living in fear
stories.summary: An appeal to overturn the 10-year-old Obergefell v. Hodges Supreme Court ruling that legalized same-sex marriage in the US has been described as exhausting and terrifying by Jeremy Atherton Lin. The appeal challenges the landmark ruling and raises concerns over the erosion of LGBTQ+ rights, with fears about the future of same-sex marriage and related legal protections.

stories.headline: 'I can't die' Ohio parents whose son has a rare disease are terrified he will outlive them
stories.summary: Karen and Jeff Groff, parents from Upper Arlington, Ohio, have been reading their son Danny Groff children's books for nearly four decades. Danny has Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, a severe epilepsy causing brain damage and lifelong disabilities. With Danny now 39 years old, the couple is terrified he might outlive them given his rare condition that affects many individuals in the US and worldwide. The family faces challenges managing his care and future.

stories.headline: Rats going nuts at California almond orchards
stories.summary: Rodent expert Roger Baldwin from the University of California, Davis, reports a huge increase in rat activity causing significant damage to California's almond orchards. The rat invasion has resulted in tens of millions in losses from damage to equipment and crops across over 100,000 acres. Authorities and farmers are scrambling to control the infestation through research, rat control education, and interviews to find solutions.

stories.headline: Peace in Trump era has a new playbook
stories.summary: President Donald Trump is determined to make a deal swiftly to end the war in Ukraine, signaling a shift in diplomacy. While concern exists about Trump's willingness to concede to Russia in his push to win the Nobel Peace Prize, America’s allies and leaders of Ukraine and Europe watch closely. The upcoming summit in the East Room aims to encourage a ceasefire before Ukraine faces further territorial losses from Russia's invasion.

stories.headline: Tiny Trump Tower Firm Becomes First Family’s Go-To Dealmaker
stories.summary: Donald Trump’s family business, particularly a small firm tied to Trump Tower, has played an increasingly pivotal role as a trusted financial partner for the Trump family, focusing on buying low and investing smartly. The firm has attracted scrutiny from Democratic lawmakers and prosecutors as it grows its influence on Wall Street and beyond, with CEO Anthony Hayes directly involved in the company’s dealings and opportunities for expansion into the defense sector and real estate.

stories.headline: A U.S. Journey Gave an Injured Boy a New Chance
stories.summary: Doctors in Gaza were resigned to an injured boy dying, but his mother refused to give up hope. The story recounts a tragic explosion in Ibrahim Abouwda’s neighborhood that left him severely wounded, and how urgent efforts were made by family and community members to save the child. Despite overwhelming odds, the boy’s survival is a testament to resilience amid conflict, underscoring the human cost of ongoing violence in the region.

stories.headline: Musk Cools on New Party Idea, Weighs Backing Vance in 2028
stories.summary: Billionaire Elon Musk seems to be stepping back from his initial enthusiasm for a new political party as he pivots towards supporting a powerful Republican candidate for the 2028 presidential election. Musk is said to be closely monitoring emerging political developments and is considering endorsing Justice Department President JD Vance as a potential candidate, while funding this political movement with nearly $300 million. The move might influence Trump and other Republicans' strategies for 2024 and beyond.

stories.headline: President Weighs Air Aid To EU in Ukraine
stories.summary: President Trump has indicated the U.S. is ready to support European security forces in Ukraine with air aid but will not deploy American ground troops as part of this assistance. This stance was emphasized during discussions with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, as well as other European leaders, highlighting a preference to avoid direct American ground involvement even while supporting defense efforts against Russian forces.

stories.headline: Union Leaders for Air Canada's Flight Attendants Announce Return to Work
stories.summary: Air Canada flight attendants have agreed to return to work following a new deal reached with union leaders, ending a three-day strike that disrupted hundreds of flights. The resolution appears to address key concerns of the workers, bringing relief to travelers and the airline industry amid ongoing labor challenges.

stories.headline: Trump: No US troops to Ukraine
stories.summary: President Donald Trump assured that U.S. troops would not be sent to defend Ukraine against Russia after discussions with Russian President Vladimir Putin and amidst ongoing conflict concerns. Trump emphasized Ukraine's hopes to regain the Crimean Peninsula from Russia are 'impossible' and declined to rule out peacekeeping roles but maintained that U.S. boots are not on the ground as part of any plan. This stance comes amid rising tensions and diplomatic talks involving multiple leaders.

stories.headline: City and suburbs cleaning up after rounds of heavy storms
stories.summary: Residents and officials across Chicago and its suburbs are assessing damage and beginning cleanup efforts following severe storms and flooding. Workers and volunteers have been distributing supplies such as disinfectants and protective gear, attending to injured residents, and providing support in affected neighborhoods. Local officials stressed the need for community support and long-term repair due to extensive damage to homes and infrastructure.

stories.headline: Terrible artist draws terrible portraits — and finds a niche
stories.summary: Jacob Ryan Reno, an artist known for his deliberately bad portraits, has gained attention in Chicago. Despite his self-confessed lack of traditional artistic skill, Reno's humorous and unique approach has attracted an audience, including customers who humorously appreciate his style. His work plays with the perception of artistic talent and challenges conventional expectations in portrait art.

stories.headline: Group 'rolling the dice' on remapping
stories.summary: Ex-Obama officials and bipartisan pairs from President Barack Obama's administration are pushing efforts to stop lawmakers from directly drawing their own district boundaries in Illinois. The Fair Maps Illinois group, led by Chicago Democrat William Daley, aims to reduce partisan influence and prevent GOP gerrymandering by advocating for citizen-driven amendments to district mapping, though there are legal and political challenges ahead.

stories.headline: Pediatrics group veers on COVID shot
stories.summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) has recommended COVID-19 vaccinations for children aged 6 months to 23 months, diverging from earlier guidance by RFK Jr. and addressing a wider effort by medical bodies to counter misinformation. Despite criticism and concerns about the safety of vaccinating young children, especially with new respiratory season approaching, the AAP highlights the importance of vaccines. Meanwhile, a University of Minnesota-led vaccine project is countering federal misinformation by pooling data from multiple studies on vaccine safety and effectiveness against COVID-19 and other respiratory viruses.

stories.headline: Life-saving tech will be flown in
stories.summary: M Health Fairview is enhancing its emergency response capabilities for cardiac arrest patients with a new helicopter program equipped with advanced heart pump technology (ECMO). This initiative aims to reduce response times by transporting critical patients swiftly and providing extracorporeal membrane oxygenation, an advanced cardiac support treatment, within 30 minutes of a cardiac arrest event in the Princeton, Minnesota area. Local hospitals and specialists are collaborating to ensure patients receive timely and effective care to improve survival rates.

stories.headline: Ellison has filed a lawsuit vs. TikTok
stories.summary: Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison has filed a lawsuit against TikTok, accusing the social media platform of being 'digital nicotine' that is addictive and harmful to children. The lawsuit claims TikTok designs its platform to maximize user engagement and advertising profits at the expense of children's well-being. This legal action is part of a broader movement involving multiple states targeting TikTok over similar concerns, emphasizing the platform’s impact on youth mental health and safety.

stories.headline: Mitchell Lake has healthiest fish, DNR says
stories.summary: Mitchell Lake in Fifty Lakes, Minnesota, is recognized as having the healthiest fish in the state by the Department of Natural Resources (DNR). The lake, located in Crow Wing County, is noted for its pristine water quality supported by its natural geography and careful development practices. Unlike larger neighboring lakes, Mitchell Lake's fish health is exceptional, providing an ideal habitat free from invasive species, and is regarded as one of the best places for fish in Minnesota.

stories.headline: Trump seeks fast deal with Russia, Ukraine
stories.summary: President Donald Trump is pushing to make a quick deal to end the ongoing war in Ukraine. While this is positive news for peace efforts, it raises concerns among leaders in Ukraine and Europe about possible concessions to Russia. Trump’s campaign to win the Nobel Peace Prize has mobilized European leaders to back Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy. Despite this, Russian President Vladimir Putin has dismissed ceasefire talks at a recent meeting with Trump.

stories.headline: DeSantis names Caruso as PBC clerk, comptroller
stories.summary: Veteran Republican legislator Mike Caruso was appointed Palm Beach County's newest county clerk and comptroller by Governor Ron DeSantis. Caruso, a Republican from Delray Beach and one of DeSantis' close allies, fills the vacancy left by Joe Abruzzo's resignation. Caruso is noted for his support of DeSantis and alignment with the GOP presidential nominee.

stories.headline: Crowded rides
stories.summary: Parents are voicing frustration on social media over overcrowded school buses in Palm Beach County, where students are forced to stand or sit in aisles during trips. The Palm Beach County School District acknowledges the issue as temporary due to increased ridership and logistical challenges early in the school year. Officials are working diligently to balance bus routes and reduce overcrowding to improve student transportation.

stories.headline: Reservoir plan faces sharp resistance
stories.summary: Nicasio residents, including homeowners Monica and Mike Seybold, express concern over a Marin Municipal Water District plan to expand the Nicasio Reservoir due to increased flood risks from heavy rainfall and creek flooding. The district’s proposal includes installing a 280-foot-long inflatable rubber gate to boost the reservoir's capacity by about 3,700 acre-feet, which residents fear will harm their community.

stories.headline: Claims on crash get key facts wrong
stories.summary: The White House inaccurately linked California's sanctuary policies to a fatal crash in Florida, which was caused by an undocumented semitruck driver with a federal work permit. The administration's assertions have sparked a debate about immigration policy and led to a renewed conflict between President Trump and California Governor Gavin Newsom, amid efforts to remove immigrants from the country.

stories.headline: Experts dispute GOP’s stance on redistricting
stories.summary: Governor Gavin Newsom's plan to add House seats in California is being challenged by Republicans who claim the state constitution and federal law prohibit the plan, though the law does not support their claims. Critics argue that the Democrats' proposed redistricting measure is a partisan strategy and likely unconstitutional, and Assembly member Carl DeMaio accused Newsom and Democrats of violating the Constitution.

stories.headline: ‘Boring’ is the goal for S.F. school officials
stories.summary: San Francisco school officials, aiming for stability, kicked off the school year with the goal of avoiding turmoil such as strikes or closures. Superintendent Maria Su emphasized maintaining a steady operation focused on student learning, with over 95% of classrooms staffed by qualified teachers, signaling a focus on consistency amid previous years of conflict in the district.

stories.headline: Why Putin Thinks Russia Has the Upper Hand
stories.summary: Russia, under Vladimir Putin, appears to hold the military advantage in the present conflict with Ukraine, capitalizing on recent successful military maneuvers and stabilization of front lines. Kremlin forces have leveraged financial and social benefits to maintain troop morale, contributing to perceived upper hand in the ongoing confrontation.

stories.headline: A Puzzling, and Staggering, Link to Colon Cancer for Marathoners
stories.summary: Recent studies indicate marathon runners might face a higher risk of advanced colon cancer adenomas compared to the general population. Analysis of 100 runners showed a significant prevalence of these growths, suggesting intense physical activity may have unexpected long-term health impacts. Researchers are continuing to study this correlation for better understanding.

stories.headline: Pulling the ‘Crime Card’ Proves Politically Dicey
stories.summary: President Trump labeled Washington a city plagued by crime to justify his political attacks, but statistics reveal that crime does not exist to the extent claimed. While crime rates do reflect some challenges, much of the public remains unconvinced by the political narrative that exaggerates the dangers. This tug-of-war reflects broader divisions about perceptions of safety and political motives.

stories.headline: For Economy, Clouds Darker But May Pass
stories.summary: Economic indicators suggest a slight downturn as inflation and labor market signals head in a less favorable direction, although signs are still mixed. Experts from BNP Paribas warn that a prolonged economic slowdown may be underway but also emphasize uncertainty in forecasting near-term trends. The U.S. economy faces risks but could avoid a major recession if conditions stabilize.

stories.headline: Trump Rejects Sending U.S. Troops to Ukraine As Part of a Peace Deal
stories.summary: President Trump ruled out American ground troop deployment to Ukraine amid ongoing diplomacy with Russia and European leaders. He suggested support could come through air assistance but maintained the stance against boots on the ground. This position complicates peace negotiations and reflects tensions about U.S. military involvement in the conflict between Russia and Ukraine.

stories.headline: Monsoon, a Giver of Life, Also Brings Death
stories.summary: Devastating floods in Beshonai, Pakistan, triggered by monsoon rains, have killed over 300 people. The weather phenomenon, essential to the region's agriculture and water supply, also causes significant loss of life and property damage. The community faces recovery challenges amid the ongoing threat of seasonal flooding.

stories.headline: Community radio host shining light on lives of everyday people
stories.summary: Nikki Brooks, a South Kansas City native, is making her mark on the local media scene as the host of "On Air with Nikki Brooks" on KKFI Kansas City Community Radio. Coming from no radio experience, she entered the field through a community training program and balances her role with healthcare and family responsibilities. Brooks uses her platform to highlight voices and stories that are often overlooked and has developed a strong bond with her audience through her commitment to real-world perspectives.

stories.headline: Can fallen KCI artwork be replaced and made safe?
stories.summary: The Kansas City International Airport's entryway, left without the kinetic artwork "The Air Up There" by Nick Cave, is raising safety and replacement concerns. The artwork, consisting of some 2,800 wind spinners, was removed after one spinner fell in October 2024. The sculpture cost nearly $1 million and is part of the city's 1% for art program. The airport authority voted not to reinstall the sculpture, as it may not be feasible or safe. The piece was a prominent public artwork, and replacing it is complicated due to construction and safety considerations.

stories.headline: Missouri AG Bailey resigning to join Trump administration
stories.summary: Missouri Attorney General Andrew Bailey will resign next month to serve as co-deputy director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation under the Trump administration. Bailey announced his resignation effective September 8, confirmed in a press release. He will join alongside Dan Bongino as co-deputy director, continuing a path of Missouri attorneys quickly advancing to federal roles. Bailey emphasized his commitment to service and said Missouri always will be home. He will follow in the footsteps of recent predecessors who used the post as a gateway to higher federal positions.

stories.headline: Candidate defends shooting of contractor in social media post
stories.summary: Lisa Walker-Yeager, a political candidate running for local government offices in Wyandotte County, defended herself in a social media post after facing criminal charges for shooting a contractor last fall during a payment dispute. She claimed in the post that she acted to save her daughter's life and manage her financial troubles, and clarified the incident happened in an attempt to protect her family. Walker-Yeager is running for the November general election while under criminal scrutiny.

stories.headline: Citizens question housing industry donations
stories.summary: Some county residents in unincorporated Hamilton County raised concerns about campaign contributions from the housing industry influencing county commissioners' votes. About 44% of campaign contributions to county commissioners came from donors connected to housing industry interests, including builders, developers, real estate agents, and others. Residents are questioning the potential impact of these donations on official decisions.

stories.headline: Doctors find high cancer rate in runners
stories.summary: A study presented at an American Society of Clinical Oncology conference revealed that three patients who were young, active runners, regularly running ultramarathons, were found to have advanced colon cancer. Their cases puzzled doctors as they were otherwise healthy and had no known risk factors. Research indicated the rate of advanced adenomas was higher in extreme runners, suggesting that despite running's health benefits, some risks may exist.

stories.headline: Show of force: City Council members met by crowd as pay raises discussed
stories.summary: During a City Council meeting, a significant turnout of uniformed police officers and firefighters gathered to hear discussions about pay raises. Andrew Peker, training director for the Chattanooga Police Department, expressed concerns about low pay compared to other agencies and the importance of keeping their families supported. The meeting also included public feedback on a proposed property tax increase to fund pay raises for first responders and other city priorities.

stories.headline: Trump says he won’t send US ground troops to Ukraine
stories.summary: President Donald Trump stated that no American ground troops would be sent to Ukraine as part of a potential peace agreement with Russia. He emphasized diplomatic efforts to stop the war and prevent future Russian aggression, while leaving open the possibility of sending other support such as air support. Trump's remarks came amid ongoing talks with leaders from European nations and Ukraine regarding ending the conflict.

stories.headline: Who are most vocal dissenters of Newsom’s redistricting plan?
stories.summary: California lawmakers held a public meeting to discuss a redistricting plan aiming to redraw congressional districts in response to Texas legislature's actions. Some vocal dissenters include former commission members who opposed the recent proposal to redraw districts, viewing it as a political power grab that could affect Democratic representation ahead of elections. Their testimony in committee meetings reflects ongoing debate over the fairness of district maps.

stories.headline: Trump says US won’t send peacekeeping troops to Ukraine
stories.summary: Former President Donald Trump stated that the U.S. will not deploy troops to Ukraine as part of any peace agreement, emphasizing that there would be no boots on the ground. Trump highlighted ongoing diplomatic talks among European leaders and the U.S., while underscoring Russia’s ongoing attacks on Ukraine. The statement contrasts with other international efforts and highlights the complex stance on U.S. involvement in the conflict.

stories.headline: 'Failing' public records law hinders government transparency
stories.summary: Sacramento drivers have accused peace officers of wrongdoing under California's public records law, which has been criticized for allowing law enforcement to withhold documents using lengthy criteria. Black Lives Matter and others have highlighted how the law stifles government transparency, with a local chapter and civil liberties union involved. Efforts to obtain relevant documents have been hindered by long-standing procedures involving multiple agencies.

stories.headline: GOP takes redistricting fight to California Supreme Court
stories.summary: California Republicans have filed an emergency petition with the California Supreme Court to challenge the state's redistricting plan, accusing Democrats of violating the constitution by pushing political power away from voters. The petition was made during an Assembly Elections Committee hearing and follows Democratic moves to respond to Texas Legislature's new maps.

stories.headline: House set to vote on redrawn maps
stories.summary: The Texas House is poised to vote on newly redistricted maps amid a political fight between Democrats and Republicans. Several northern Texas districts are expected to be reshaped with Republicans gaining favorable boundaries. The bill aims to replace a previous plan invalidated by Democrats in the House.

stories.headline: Texas Dems reinforce colleague’s lock-in fight
stories.summary: A Fort Worth lawmaker's sit-in on the Texas House floor garnered support from fellow Democrats who opposed a controversial new congressional map. Protesters have been present since Monday to resist what they see as government overreach in the redistricting process, affecting the member's ability to leave or vote.

stories.headline: Nurturing home-grown talent
stories.summary: Toi Clark, a former U.S. Army Airborne specialist and 32-year-old mechanic, exemplifies efforts to close workforce skills gaps through in-house training programs. Clark's experience highlights how firms are tackling workforce development by supporting and training local talent, fostering career growth in automotive technology.

stories.headline: Trump: No U.S. troops
stories.summary: President Donald Trump assured that U.S. troops would not be sent to defend Ukraine against Russia, contradicting recent speculation. He labeled Ukraine's hopes to join NATO and regain Crimea as impossible, and reiterated previous assurances amid discussions with global leaders and concerns over ongoing conflict.

stories.headline: Appeals court grants stay on firearm waiting periods
stories.summary: A federal appeals court in Denver granted a stay against New Mexico's law mandating a seven-day waiting period for firearm purchases, a ruling that questions the constitutionality of the waiting period and could impact similar laws nationwide. The stay was issued after legal challenges argued the law placed an unconstitutional burden on citizens and could affect firearm purchases throughout the state, except for certain permit-holders and law enforcement.

stories.headline: State office projects ‘new money’ to hit $485M for FY27
stories.summary: New Mexico's state cabinet secretary Wayne Propst announced projections of nearly $485 million in new money or revenue beyond the current budget for fiscal year 2027. Despite persistent economic uncertainties, the state's financial outlook remains strong with $14.1 billion in recurring revenues projected. Discussions highlighted the potential to fund governmental priorities with this unexpected revenue growth.

stories.headline: Elephant Butte reservoir at 4% as officials discuss Rio Grande suit
stories.summary: Elephant Butte Irrigation District officials painted a bleak picture of the reservoir levels in Southern New Mexico, which stands at only 4% capacity. The irrigation district distributes water to irrigators in the region and discussed the impact of a recent Supreme Court decision that struck down a 2022 water agreement with Texas and Colorado. Panelists focused on the need for conservation in the Lower Rio Grande amidst dwindling water supplies this year.

stories.headline: More balance on budget?
stories.summary: Santa Fe city council is considering an overhaul of its budgeting process amid claims from councilors that it is dominated by the mayor, leaving them little say early in the process. Council members debated funding for a second parks crew, with some arguing the budget was mostly finished and required amendments from the mayor for additional funds. Council discussions revealed differing opinions on prioritizing budget amendments before approving the full council budget.

stories.headline: Deportations bad for SW Detroit businesses
stories.summary: In Southwest Detroit, the celebration of the Quinceañera marks a transition to womanhood. Many in the largely Latino migrant community rely on local businesses like Araceli Hernandez's Florbella Salon. Hernandez recently had an appointment canceled after the client's father was detained by Immigration Customs and Enforcement and deported. Small business owners in Michigan's largest Latino community say they are reeling amid President Donald Trump's aggressive deportation campaign causing customers to avoid the area. They describe a pervasive climate of fear around immigration enforcement, negatively impacting business revenue.

stories.headline: Denser housing demands test cities
stories.summary: Growing demand for multifamily housing in some Metro Detroit communities is creating a mismatch in some areas with more single-family homes, raising tensions in some areas as city leaders update their master plans. From Royal Oak to Ann Arbor, several communities are revising their master plans to better reflect the types of households they have, increasing density in some areas while trying to pay attention to aesthetics like building heights. Both Detroit and Ann Arbor are updating their master plans with a focus on multifamily housing such as apartment buildings, duplexes and condominiums. Royal Oak city officials noted that their updated master plan allows denser housing for the first time since 1999. The changes are to create more densely populated housing.
people: Royal Oak City Manager Joe Gacich

stories.headline: Trump: No U.S. troops to assist Ukraine
stories.summary: President Donald Trump stated that the United States will not send troops to assist Ukraine after its war with Russia. Speaking on Fox News, Trump reiterated that while the U.S. would be involved in security guarantees for Ukraine, it would not deploy military forces. He referenced talks with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and other European leaders, emphasizing that the U.S. would support Ukraine in other ways but is not putting troops on the ground. Trump also underscored his willingness to help European nations as part of the security discussions.

stories.headline: Pediatricians, CDC clash on COVID shots
stories.summary: For the first time in 30 years, the American Academy of Pediatrics is substantially diverging from U.S. government vaccine recommendations on COVID-19 shots, which has created confusion. The divergent recommendations came shortly after the CDC advisory committee gave guidance that the vaccine benefits are outweighed by risks for children ages 6 months to 2 years. The AAP still strongly recommends COVID-19 vaccinations for children six months to 2 years, while doses are also advised for older children if their parents are vaccinated. This divergence is causing uncertainty among parents and healthcare providers.

stories.headline: Strategists say Garrity formidable opponent
stories.summary: Political strategists view Pennsylvania Democratic and Republican Treasurer Stacy Garrity as a formidable contender in her bid for re-election. With a history as a good state treasurer and key support from diverse political figures, she poses an uphill challenge to her Democratic opponent Josh Shapiro. Garrity's fundraising and public recognition contribute to her strong position in the critical swing state race for governor in 2026.

stories.headline: TRUMP: WILL NOT SEND U.S. TROOPS
