stories.summary: President Donald Trump stated that U.S. troops will not be sent to help defend Ukraine against Russia despite tensions and talks at the White House. Trump insists there will be no American troop involvement in Ukraine, emphasizing his control over U.S. military decisions through the end of his term in January 2029. The announcement came amid ongoing diplomatic discussions involving NATO and Ukrainian leadership.

stories.headline: Stadium expansion planned
stories.summary: The owner of Station Square's Highmark Stadium aims to transform Pittsburgh into a four-sport city with a $125 million-$150 million expansion adding up to 9,500 seats and other amenities. Pittsburgh Riverhounds and Riveters owner Truffy Shallenberger plans to increase stadium capacity from 5,500 to 15,000 to qualify for the United Soccer League's new Division One launching in 2028. The stadium expansion is funded by a public-private partnership.

stories.headline: 'Definitely a special day'
stories.summary: Seventeen years after a liver transplant, Duquesne University freshman Alaina Janet's move-in is a significant milestone and emotional moment for her family. Diagnosed with biliary atresia at birth, and after a lengthy treatment and transplant history at UPMC Children's Hospital, Alaina is now studying nursing and living with her family close by in Pittsburgh. The family expressed the deep personal importance of the day and the journey they have endured together.

stories.headline: 2nd driver is sentenced up to 4½ years
stories.summary: In a tragic van crash that killed fifteen-year-old Samantha Kalkbrenner nearly two years ago, the second driver involved, Andrew Voigt, received a sentence of up to 4½ years in state prison. Each driver was considered to have contributed to the accident. The sentencing followed extensive court proceedings held before Judge Bruce Beemer at the Allegheny County Courthouse. Samantha's family and those affected continue to grieve the loss.

stories.headline: State has long used mail-in ballots
stories.summary: President Donald Trump is seeking to eliminate mail-in voting and the use of voting machines less than a year after nearly 1.6 million Wisconsin residents cast ballots by mail when Trump won the 2024 presidential election. Trump plans to lead a movement to end the use of absentee voting and decommission voting machines ahead of the 2026 election by signing an executive order. Ending mail-in voting would eliminate a practice legal in Wisconsin since 1862, though newer laws allow residents who will not be at home to vote by mail.

stories.headline: Canada’s wildfires reflect tough environmental issue
stories.summary: Amid heavy views and unhealthy air quality caused by Canadian wildfires, some Midwest lawmakers are blaming either the nation’s forest policy or climate change for the fires. U.S. Representatives Tom Tiffany, Glenn Grothman, Wisconsin state Rep. Calvin Callahan, and Republicans have voiced concerns about wildfire smoke and filed a formal complaint to Canadian and U.S. authorities. They argue that smoky summers are due solely to wildfire management policies in Canada, raising questions about forest management and environmental responsibility.

stories.headline: FEMA flood assessors are expected to visit this week
stories.summary: Federal Emergency Management Agency officials will arrive in southeast Wisconsin to assess flood damage and provide aid. Joint recovery teams composed of FEMA and state officials will conduct interviews with affected homeowners, renters, and business owners to document storm damage and flooding. This is an important step for receiving federal aid, and will help officials determine the extent of damage as the state requests assistance from the federal government.

stories.headline: Where everyone stands on road funding amid budget impasse
stories.summary: Michigan faces a potential state government shutdown with limited time to pass a budget. Disagreements persist between Republicans, Governor Whitmer, and Democrats about funding priorities, including road repair and education. The House and Senate have not finalized a clear plan, with ongoing debates about the use of federal funds and tax considerations. Lawmakers have until the end of September to reach an agreement and avoid shutdown impacts.

stories.headline: How effective has recycling plastics been? Not very.
stories.summary: Talks aimed at a global treaty to cut plastic pollution have made little progress, with only 6% of produced plastics being recycled. Challenges include the complexity of plastic types and color, the cost of recycling, and lack of agreement among major plastic-producing nations. Plastic pollution continues to rise, with plastics contributing significantly to greenhouse gas emissions and environmental harm.

stories.headline: Proposed pilot program would aim to reduce K-3 class sizes
stories.summary: Schools in four Michigan districts could receive a $65 million boost to help maintain smaller class sizes for K-3 students under newly proposed legislation. Two bills introduced in the state Senate would fund eligible local schools to keep class sizes between 17 to 19 students. If successful, this initiative would support better individualized instruction and literacy development in early grades.

stories.headline: NO ORDINARY GARAGE SALE
stories.summary: A Northwest Side warehouse is hosting an auction featuring a collection of unique classic and muscle cars. The sale offers enthusiasts a rare chance to acquire some extraordinary vehicles.

stories.headline: FORMER JAN. 6 DEFENDANT GETS 17 YEARS FOR CRASH THAT KILLED SKOKIE WOMAN
stories.summary: A former participant in the January 6 events has been sentenced to 17 years in prison for a crash that resulted in the death of a woman from Skokie. The case has attracted attention due to the defendant's prior involvement in the Capitol incident.

stories.headline: Veterans sue VA, say agency 'flouting' Supreme Court ruling by denying education benefits
stories.summary: Veterans have filed a lawsuit against the Department of Veterans Affairs, accusing it of ignoring a Supreme Court ruling by continuing to deny education benefits to eligible individuals. This watchdog report highlights ongoing challenges faced by veterans seeking these benefits.

stories.headline: Mayor calls for state, feds to help S.W. Side residents hit by flooding twice in a month
stories.summary: The mayor is urging state and federal governments to provide assistance to South West Side residents who have suffered two floods in a month. Efforts are underway to address the impact and prevent future occurrences.

stories.headline: Does Chicago have too many steak restaurants?
stories.summary: An analysis of Chicago's dining scene questions whether there is an oversaturation of steak restaurants in the city. The feature explores the current restaurant landscape and consumer preferences.
